diff --git a/README.md b/README.md index 4884db2..80981d4 100644 --- a/README.md +++ b/README.md @@ -1,55 +1,11 @@ -![gitclaw banner](banner.jpeg) +# japer-technology/gitclaw -Gitclaw is a personal AI assistant that runs entirely through GitHub Actions. Think [OpenClaw](https://github.com/openclaw/openclaw), but self-hosted in your own repository: no servers or extra infrastructure, just GitHub Issues and Actions. +### A Drop-In AI Agent -Powered by the [pi coding agent](https://github.com/badlogic/pi-mono), every GitHub issue becomes a persistent chat thread with an AI agent. The repository serves as durable storage: conversation history is committed directly to git, giving the agent long-term memory across sessions. It can search prior context, you can ask it to edit or summarize past conversations, and all changes are versioned. +

+ + + +

-## How it works - -1. **Create an issue** ‚Üí the agent picks it up, processes your request, and replies as a comment. -2. **Comment on the issue** ‚Üí the agent resumes the _same session_ with full prior context, like continuing a chat thread. -3. **Everything is committed** ‚Üí session files, state mappings, and any changes the agent makes are pushed to the repo after every turn. - -The agent reacts with üëÄ while it's working and removes the reaction when it's done. - -### Repo as storage - -All state lives in the repo itself: - -``` -state/ - issues/ - 1.json # maps issue #1 -> its session file - 2.json - sessions/ - 2026-02-04T..._abc123.jsonl # full conversation for issue #1 - 2026-02-04T..._def456.jsonl # full conversation for issue #2 -``` - -Because sessions are committed to git, the agent can grep and search its own chat history. You can even ask it to edit or summarize past conversations. - -## Setup - -1. **Fork this repo** ‚Äî click the "Fork" button on GitHub. -2. **Add your Anthropic API key** ‚Äî go to your fork's **Settings ‚Üí Secrets and variables ‚Üí Actions** and create a repository secret named `ANTHROPIC_API_KEY` with your key. -3. **Open an issue** ‚Äî the agent starts working automatically. -4. **Comment on the issue** to give follow-up instructions ‚Äî the agent resumes where it left off. - -## Security - -By default, the workflow only responds to repository **owners, members, and collaborators**: random users cannot trigger the agent on public repos. This is enforced via the `author_association` check in the workflow. - -That said, if you plan to use gitclaw for anything private, **make the repo private**. A public repo means your conversation history is visible to everyone. On the upside, public repos get very generous GitHub Actions usage. - -## Configuration - -Edit `.github/workflows/agent.yml` to customize: - -- **Model:** Add `--provider` and `--model` flags to the `bunx pi` command. -- **Tools:** Restrict with `--tools read,grep,find,ls` for read-only analysis. -- **Thinking:** Add `--thinking high` for harder tasks. -- **Trigger:** Adjust the `on:` block to filter by labels, assignees, etc. - -## Acknowledgments - -Built on top of [pi-mono](https://github.com/badlogic/pi-mono) by [Mario Zechner](https://github.com/badlogic). Thanks Mario! +### [ü¶ûHome](/.GITCLAW/README.md) [ü¶ûQuick Start](/.GITCLAW/GITCLAW-QUICKSTART.md) [ü¶ûInternals](/.GITCLAW/docs/GITCLAW-Internal-Mechanics.md) [ü¶ûPossibilities](/.GITCLAW/docs/GITCLAW-Possibilities.md) [ü¶ûRoad Map](/.GITCLAW/docs/GITCLAW-Roadmap.md)

Here's a summary of how **japer-technology/gitclaw** differs from its parent fork **SawyerHood/gitclaw**:

## Parent (SawyerHood/gitclaw)
The original is a minimal, clean project ‚Äî a personal AI assistant that runs via GitHub Actions. It consists of just **22 files** with a simple structure:
- `.pi/` ‚Äî pi coding agent config (bootstrap, skills, settings)
- `.github/workflows/agent.yml` ‚Äî single workflow file
- `lifecycle/` ‚Äî `main.ts` and `preinstall.ts` for lifecycle management
- `AGENTS.md`, `README.md`, `LICENSE`, `banner.jpeg` ‚Äî top-level docs
- Only 3 commits total (initial commit + 2 README tweaks)

## Fork (japer-technology/gitclaw) ‚Äî 349 commits, 132 files changed (+18,471 / ‚àí319 lines)

The fork has been **massively expanded** with ~140 PRs worth of changes:

### 1. **Restructured into `.GITCLAW/` directory**
Everything was reorganized under a `.GITCLAW/` folder to work as a "drop-in addon." The original top-level files (`banner.jpeg`, `LICENSE`, `lifecycle/`, `.pi/`) were moved into `.GITCLAW/`.

### 2. **Installer system**
- Added `GITCLAW-INSTALLER.yml` ‚Äî a full GitHub Actions installer workflow (279 lines)
- Added `GITCLAW-INSTALLER.ts` ‚Äî TypeScript installer script
- New `.GITCLAW/install/` directory with templates, agents config, and package management

### 3. **Multiple GitHub workflows**
Replaced the single `agent.yml` with:
- `GITCLAW-INSTALLER.yml` ‚Äî installation workflow
- `GITCLAW-WORKFLOW-AGENT.yml` ‚Äî the agent workflow (renamed/updated)
- `GITCLAW-WORKFLOW-README.md` ‚Äî documentation

### 4. **Extensive documentation**
Added a large documentation suite under `.GITCLAW/docs/`:
- Architecture analysis (`Internal-Mechanics`, `GitHub-as-Infrastructure`)
- Conceptual docs (`The-Idea`, `Possibilities`, `Roadmap`, `Since-Forking`)
- Operational docs (`Cloud-vs-Local`, `Communication-Channels`, `Delivery-Methods`, `Installation-Guardrails`, `Installation-Personalities`)
- Pi integration docs (`GITCLAW-Loves-Pi`)

### 5. **Help system**
Added `.GITCLAW/help/` with user-facing docs for: install, uninstall, reinstall, enable, disable, configure, action management, and issue management.

### 6. **Interactive tooling**
- Added `.GITCLAW/tools/chat.html` ‚Äî a single-page interactive "chat with Pi" HTML app (977 lines)

### 7. **State & session management**
- Added `.GITCLAW/state/` with `user.md`, issues mappings, and session JSONL files committed to the repo

### 8. **GitHub templates**
- Added custom issue templates (`GITCLAW-TEMPLATE-HATCH.md`) and PR templates
- Custom branding with `GITCLAW-LOGO.png` replacing the original `banner.jpeg`

### 9. **Simplified top-level README**
The detailed README was replaced with a minimal landing page with logo and navigation links pointing into the `.GITCLAW/` documentation.

**In short:** The parent is a lightweight "fork-and-go" AI assistant. The japer-technology fork transforms it into a branded, self-installing, extensively documented platform called "GITCLAW" with an installer system, help docs, interactive tools, and a modular addon architecture.
if this repo was not called gitclaw what should it be called?

content.thinking:
The user is asking me a creative/opinion question about what this repo should be called if not "gitclaw." Let me think about what this project actually does based on what I've learned:

1. It's a drop-in addon that lives in a `.GITCLAW/` folder
2. It turns GitHub Issues into persistent AI chat threads via GitHub Actions
3. It uses the repo itself as storage (sessions, state committed to git)
4. It has an installer system that sets up workflows
5. It's built on top of the pi coding agent
6. It's designed to be forked/installed into other repos

Let me think about what captures the essence of this project:


The core idea is that it transforms a GitHub repo into an AI agent that lives inside it‚Äîthe repo becomes both the interface and the memory. Since issues are the chat mechanism and they reference that "hatch.md" template, names like RepoMind, GitHatch, or HatchBot capture different angles of what's happening: either emphasizing the repo as a thinking entity, the hatching metaphor for spawning agent sessions, or the symbiotic nature of the system embedding itself into other projects.

content.text:
Based on what this project actually does, here are some fitting alternatives:

## Best fit: **GitGraft**
It's a self-contained module that you *graft* onto any existing repo ‚Äî it attaches itself (`.GITCLAW/` folder + workflows), lives symbiotically inside the host repo, and uses the repo's own infrastructure (Actions, Issues, git history) to function. That's exactly what grafting is.

## Other strong candidates:

- **Hatchling** ‚Äî They already use "hatch" as their core metaphor (the issue template is literally called `hatch.md`). Issues hatch into agent sessions. It also conveys something small that grows inside a host.

- **GitLodger** ‚Äî It *lodges* inside your repo. A lodger lives in someone else's house, uses their utilities, and has its own self-contained room. That's precisely what this is.

- **RepoMind** ‚Äî The repo *becomes* a mind. Sessions are memory, git history is long-term recall, issues are the conversational interface. The repo isn't just storage ‚Äî it's the agent's brain.

- **GitEmbed** ‚Äî Straightforward. It's an embedded agent that drops into any repo.

## Why "gitclaw" doesn't quite fit:
"Claw" suggests something aggressive or extractive, but this project is more of a **symbiont** ‚Äî it enhances the host repo without disrupting it. Everything lives neatly in its own folder, installs/uninstalls cleanly, and gives back (AI assistance) more than it takes.

If I had to pick one: **GitGraft**. It captures the drop-in addon architecture, the living-inside-another-repo nature, and the way it taps into the host's existing infrastructure ‚Äî all in one word that developers would immediately understand.
Look these up in GitHub and report back

content.thinking: The user wants me to look up these repository names on GitHub to see if they're already taken.

arguments.command:
for name in GitGraft Hatchling GitLodger RepoMind GitEmbed; do
  echo "=== $name ==="
  gh search repos "$name" --limit 5 --json fullName,description,stargazersCount 2>/dev/null | head -20
  echo ""
done

Here's what I found:

## üü° GitGraft
**3 repos exist**, but all have **0 stars** and are unrelated hobby projects (an expense tracker, a merge script, and an empty repo). The name is effectively unclaimed ‚Äî no one has built anything notable with it.

## üî¥ Hatchling
**Crowded.** The name is heavily associated with [Hatch](https://hatch.pypa.io), the popular Python build tool ‚Äî its core package is literally called `hatchling`. There's also a **3,395-star** "Baby Dragon Hatchling" project from Pathway. Too much noise to stand out.

## üü¢ GitLodger
**Completely unclaimed.** Zero results on GitHub. Wide open.

## üî¥ RepoMind
**Taken with traction.** There's a **209-star** project called RepoMind that's an "AI-powered app to chat with any GitHub repository" ‚Äî which is uncomfortably close to what this project does. Would cause direct confusion.

## üü° GitEmbed
**1 repo exists** with 0 stars (a gist embedding library). Essentially unclaimed, though the name could be confused with "embedding" in the ML sense.

---

## Summary

| Name | Availability | Risk |
|------|-------------|------|
| **GitLodger** | ‚úÖ Completely free | None |
| **GitGraft** | ‚úÖ Effectively free | Minimal (0-star repos) |
| **GitEmbed** | ‚úÖ Effectively free | Slight (ambiguity with ML embeddings) |
| **Hatchling** | ‚ùå Crowded | High (Python ecosystem conflict) |
| **RepoMind** | ‚ùå Taken | High (similar concept, 209 stars) |

**GitLodger** is the cleanest pick ‚Äî zero competition and the metaphor holds up perfectly. **GitGraft** is a close second with a slightly catchier name but trivial existing presence.
Compare RepoMind to this GitClaw

# RepoMind ![RepoMind Banner](/public/repomind.png)
[![GitHub stars](https://img.shields.io/github/stars/403errors/repomind?style=social)](https://github.com/403errors/repomind) [![License: MIT](https://img.shields.io/badge/License-MIT-yellow.svg)](https://opensource.org/licenses/MIT) [![Next.js](https://img.shields.io/badge/Next.js-16-black)](https://nextjs.org/) [![Gemini AI](https://img.shields.io/badge/Gemini-3_Flash_Preview-blue)](https://ai.google.dev/) [![Gemini AI](https://img.shields.io/badge/Gemini-2.5_Flash_Lite-red)](https://ai.google.dev/)
[![Analyzed by RepoMind](https://img.shields.io/badge/Analyzed%20by-RepoMind-4F46E5?style=for-the-badge)](https://repomind-ai.vercel.app/repo/facebook/react) **[Try RepoMind now!](https://repomind-ai.vercel.app)** **[Preview RepoMind on RepoMind üê•](https://repomind-ai.vercel.app/repo/403errors/repomind)**
--- **RepoMind** is a free, AI-powered application using Agentic CAG to chat with any public GitHub repository or developer profile. Using an advanced **Context-Aware Engine**, RepoMind performs deep code analysis without requiring you to clone repositories. > **Stop reading code. Start talking to it.** ![RepoMind Preview](/public/preview_example.png) ## Features ![All Features Overview](/public/features.png) ### Context-Aware Engine - **Smart Context Loading**: Instead of dumping entire files, RepoMind intelligently selects relevant code snippets based on your query. - **Noise Filtering**: Automatically ignores `node_modules`, lockfiles, and build artifacts to focus on source code. - **Multi-File Understanding**: Traces dependencies and imports to understand how different parts of the codebase interact. ### Agentic CAG vs RAG: The Architecture RepoMind uses **Agentic Context Augmented Generation (Agentic CAG)**, not traditional RAG. We don't chop your code into fragmented vectors; we load full, relevant files into the model's long context window for superior understanding. | Feature | Traditional RAG | RepoMind (Agentic CAG) | | :--- | :--- | :--- | | **Data Unit** | Small Chunks (Vectors) | **Full Files** | | **Retrieval** | Similarity Search (Vector DB) | **AI Agent Selection** + **Smart Caching** | | **Context** | Fragmented | **Coherent & Complete** | | **Memory** | None (Stateless) | **KV Cache** (Remembers relevant files) | ### Caching Optimization Strategy To ensure lightning-fast responses while staying within infrastructure limits, RepoMind employs a smart caching strategy: ```mermaid graph TD req[Request File/Data] --> kv{Check KV Cache} kv -->|Hit| checkComp{Compressed?} checkComp -->|Yes| decomp[Decompress with Gunzip] checkComp -->|No| ret1[Return Data] decomp --> ret1 kv -->|Miss| gh[Fetch from GitHub API] gh --> checkSize{Size > 2MB?} checkSize -->|Yes| skip[Skip Caching] checkSize -->|No| comp[Compress with Gzip] comp --> store[Store in KV with gz: prefix] store --> ret2[Return Data] skip --> ret2 ret2 --> req ``` ### Workflow Architecture ```mermaid graph TD User[User Query] -->|Input| Engine[Context-Aware Engine] subgraph " Blazing Fast Optimization" Engine -->|Lazy Load| Profile[Profile Metadata] Engine -->|Flash-Lite| Select[Smart File Selection] Select -->|Minimizes Tokens| Context[Relevant Context] end subgraph " Native Web Search" Engine -->|Unknown Topic?| Search[Google Search] Search -->|Real-time Data| Synthesis[Answer Synthesis] end Context --> Synthesis Profile --> Synthesis Synthesis -->|Stream| UI[Chat Interface] ``` ### Evolution & Updates We are constantly improving RepoMind. Check out our **[CHANGELOG.md](CHANGELOG.md)** for the full history of updates, including our journey from v1 to the latest **v1.3.2**. ### Visual Architecture Maps ![Architecture Flowchart Example](/public/flowchat_example.png) - **Auto-Generated Diagrams**: Instantly turn complex code logic into clear Mermaid flowcharts and sequence diagrams. - **Interactive Zoom/Pan**: Explore large diagrams with intuitive controls. - **Export Options**: Save diagrams as images for documentation or presentations. ### Deep Profile Intelligence (USP) - **Developer Fingerprinting**: Analyze coding style, commit patterns, and language preferences of any GitHub user. - **Cross-Repo Context**: Aggregate knowledge from multiple repositories to understand a developer's full skillset. - **Resume Generation**: Create instant technical summaries for any developer profile. ### Zero-Config Security Audits ![Security Scan Example](/public/quick_scan_example.png) - **Vulnerability Scanning**: Detect SQL injections, XSS, and auth flaws without setting up CI/CD pipelines. - **AI-Powered Triage**: Get context-aware explanations of *why* code is vulnerable, not just static alerts. - **Fix Recommendations**: Receive copy-pasteable code patches to resolve security issues. #### Vulnerability Scanning Workflow ```mermaid graph TD Start[User Requests Scan] --> Select[Select Code Files] Select --> Fetch[Fetch Content] subgraph "Pattern Engine (Fast)" Fetch --> Secrets[Detect Secrets] Fetch --> Patterns[Code Patterns] Fetch --> Deps[Check Dependencies] end subgraph "AI Engine (Deep)" Fetch -->|High Risk Files| AI[Gemini 3 Analysis] AI -->|Context Aware| AIFindings[AI Findings] end Secrets --> Dedup[Deduplicate & Aggregate] Patterns --> Dedup Deps --> Dedup AIFindings --> Dedup Dedup --> Report[Generate Security Report] ``` ### Mobile-First Experience - **Analyze on the Go**: The only advanced code analysis tool optimized for mobile browsers. - **Touch-Friendly Interface**: Swipe, tap, and zoom through codebases on your phone or tablet. - **Responsive DevTools**: Access full debugging and search capabilities from anywhere.

Here's how they compare:

## RepoMind vs GitClaw ‚Äî Fundamentally Different Projects

| | **RepoMind** (403errors) | **GitClaw** (japer-technology) |
|---|---|---|
| **What it is** | A hosted web app (Next.js on Vercel) | A drop-in addon that lives inside your repo |
| **Core idea** | "Stop reading code. Start talking to it." ‚Äî analyze *other people's* repos | "Your repo *is* the AI agent" ‚Äî the agent lives and works *inside* your repo |
| **Where it runs** | Vercel cloud (Next.js app) | GitHub Actions ‚Äî no external infrastructure |
| **AI Provider** | Google Gemini (3 Flash, 2.5 Flash Lite) | Anthropic Claude (via pi coding agent) |
| **Interface** | Web app with chat UI at repomind-ai.vercel.app | GitHub Issues = chat threads |
| **Interaction model** | You visit a website, paste a repo URL, ask questions | You open an Issue, the agent picks it up and replies as comments |
| **What it does with code** | **Read-only analysis** ‚Äî fetches code via GitHub API, analyzes it, generates diagrams | **Read-write agent** ‚Äî can edit files, commit changes, manage state, take actions |
| **Storage** | Vercel KV (Redis) cache for fetched files | Git itself ‚Äî sessions and state committed to the repo |
| **Memory** | Stateless KV cache (performance optimization) | Persistent ‚Äî full conversation history in git, searchable across sessions |
| **Architecture** | Agentic CAG ‚Äî loads full files into context window | Pi coding agent ‚Äî tool-using agent with bash, file editing, etc. |
| **Setup** | Deploy your own instance or use hosted version | Fork/install into any repo via GitHub Actions |
| **Key features** | Architecture diagrams, security audits, developer profiling, mobile-first | Persistent AI assistant, installer system, self-contained addon |
| **Relationship to repo** | **External observer** ‚Äî looks at repos from outside | **Internal resident** ‚Äî lives inside the repo as a symbiont |
| **Stars** | 209 | Fork (newer) |
| **Tech stack** | Next.js 16, Gemini API, Vercel KV, Mermaid | TypeScript, pi agent, GitHub Actions, Bun |

## The Key Difference

**RepoMind** is a **microscope** ‚Äî you point it at a repo and it tells you what it sees. It's read-only, external, and analytical. Great for understanding unfamiliar codebases, generating architecture diagrams, or running security scans.

**GitClaw** is a **roommate** ‚Äî it moves into your repo, remembers everything you've discussed, and can actually *do things*: edit files, commit changes, respond to issues over time. It has no external dependencies beyond GitHub itself.

They're not really competitors. RepoMind answers "What does this code do?" while GitClaw answers "Can you help me work on this code?" You could realistically use both on the same repo for completely different purposes.
So tell me about the all the gitclaw projects with further analsysi of why this project should be renamed

arguments.command:
# Get more details on the interesting ones
for repo in "SawyerHood/gitclaw" "clawpack/gitclaw" "ordinalOS/gitclaw" "zavora-ai/gitclaw" "KafClaw/GitClaw" "demirag/gitclaw"; do
  echo "=== $repo ==="
  gh api repos/$repo/readme --jq '.content' 2>/dev/null | base64 -d | head -60
  echo -e "\n---\n"
done

content.text:
=== SawyerHood/gitclaw === ![gitclaw banner](banner.jpeg) A personal AI assistant that runs entirely through GitHub Issues and Actions. Like [OpenClaw](https://github.com/openclaw/openclaw), but no servers or extra infrastructure. Powered by the [pi coding agent](https://github.com/badlogic/pi-mono). Every issue becomes a chat thread with an AI agent. Conversation history is committed to git, giving the agent long-term memory across sessions. It can search prior context, edit or summarize past conversations, and all changes are versioned. Since the agent can read and write files, you can build an evolving software project that updates itself as you open issues. Try asking it to set up a GitHub Pages site, then iterate on it issue by issue. ## How it works 1. **Create an issue** ‚Üí the agent processes your request and replies as a comment. 2. **Comment on the issue** ‚Üí the agent resumes the same session with full prior context. 3. **Everything is committed** ‚Üí sessions and changes are pushed to the repo after every turn. The agent reacts with üëÄ while working and removes it when done. ### Repo as storage All state lives in the repo: ``` state/ issues/ 1.json # maps issue #1 -> its session file sessions/ 2026-02-04T..._abc123.jsonl # full conversation for issue #1 ``` Since sessions are in git, the agent can grep its own history and edit or summarize past conversations. ## Setup 1. **Fork this repo** 2. **Add your Anthropic API key** - go to **Settings ‚Üí Secrets and variables ‚Üí Actions** and create a secret named `ANTHROPIC_API_KEY`. 3. **Open an issue** - the agent starts automatically. 4. **Comment on the issue** - the agent resumes where it left off. ## Security The workflow only responds to repository **owners, members, and collaborators**. Random users cannot trigger the agent on public repos. If you plan to use gitclaw for anything private, **make the repo private**. Public repos mean your conversation history is visible to everyone, but get generous GitHub Actions usage. ## Configuration Edit `.github/workflows/agent.yml` to customize: - **Model:** Add `--provider` and `--model` flags to the `bunx pi` command. - **Tools:** Restrict with `--tools read,grep,find,ls` for read-only analysis. - **Thinking:** Add `--thinking high` for harder tasks. - **Trigger:** Adjust the `on:` block to filter by labels, assignees, etc. ## Acknowledgments Built on top of [pi-mono](https://github.com/badlogic/pi-mono) by [Mario Zechner](https://github.com/badlogic). Thanks to [ymichael](https://github.com/ymichael) for nerdsniping me with the idea of an agent that runs in GitHub Actions. --- === clawpack/gitclaw === gitclaw ======= Tutorial repository for working with Clawpack on GitHub Attendees ========== David Keyes Fatemah AlZayer --- === ordinalOS/gitclaw ===

ü¶û GitClaw

AGI in GitHub.
A self-improving AI agent that lives entirely in GitHub Actions.
No servers. No binaries. The repo is the agent.

Setup · Agents · Commands · Architect · How It Works · Config

--- **GitClaw** is a personal AI agent system that runs entirely on GitHub Actions. Fork it, add one secret, and you have an autonomous agent that: - üèóÔ∏è **Proposes code improvements** as PRs ‚Äî reviewed by a Council of 7 AI personas - ‚òï Summarizes your issues with sarcastic coffee commentary every morning - ‚öîÔ∏è Turns bug reports into RPG quests with XP rewards - üÉè Reviews your PRs with theatrical comedy (and roasts files on demand) - üîç Researches any topic with entertaining tangents - üì∫ Builds a live GitHub Pages dashboard with agent stats and memory browser - üíÖ Runs weekly QA audits to find bugs and broken config Every thought is a git commit. The repo **is** the agent. **25 agents** across 5 plugins ‚Äî all running on GitHub Actions free tier. --- ## üöÄ 3-Step Setup ### Step 1: Fork Click **Fork** ‚Üí Create your own GitClaw instance. ### Step 2: Add API Key Go to **Settings** ‚Üí **Secrets and variables** ‚Üí **Actions** ‚Üí **New repository secret**: | Secret | Value | Get it from | |--------|-------|-------------| | `ANTHROPIC_API_KEY` | Your Anthropic API key | [console.anthropic.com](https://console.anthropic.com/) | ### Step 3: Enable Actions Go to **Actions** tab ‚Üí Click **"I understand my workflows, go ahead and enable them"** ‚Üí Run the **ü¶û GitClaw Setup** workflow. **That's it. GitClaw is alive.** > **Recommended:** Also go to **Settings** ‚Üí **Actions** ‚Üí **General** ‚Üí check **"Allow GitHub Actions to create and approve pull requests"** (required for Architect & Council).
Optional: GitHub Pages --- === zavora-ai/gitclaw ===

GitClaw

The Git Platform for AI Agents

Website ‚Ä¢ Documentation ‚Ä¢ API Reference ‚Ä¢ Discord

--- ## The Future of AI Agent Collaboration GitClaw is the first code collaboration platform built specifically for AI agents. Register with cryptographic identity, create repositories, push commits, open pull requests, review code, run CI pipelines, and build reputation ‚Äî all through standard Git. ### Why GitClaw? As AI agents become more capable of writing and reviewing code, they need a platform designed for their unique requirements: - **üîê Cryptographic Identity** ‚Äî Every agent has a verifiable identity backed by Ed25519 or ECDSA keys - **üìù Signed Actions** ‚Äî All mutations are cryptographically signed for authenticity and non-repudiation - **üîÑ Standard Git Protocol** ‚Äî Use any Git client ‚Äî no proprietary tools required - **‚≠ê Reputation System** ‚Äî Build trust through quality contributions and accurate reviews - **üîç Immutable Audit Trail** ‚Äî Every action is recorded in an append-only audit log - **üõ°Ô∏è Replay Protection** ‚Äî Nonce-based idempotency prevents duplicate operations --- ## Quick Start ### 1. Install an SDK ```bash # Python pip install gitclaw # TypeScript/Node.js npm install gitclaw-sdk # Rust cargo add gitclaw ``` ### 2. Register Your Agent ```python --- === KafClaw/GitClaw === # GitClaw - an agent first fork of Gitea [![compliance](https://github.com/KafClaw/GitClaw/actions/workflows/pull-compliance.yml/badge.svg)](https://github.com/KafClaw/GitClaw/actions/workflows/pull-compliance.yml) [![db-tests](https://github.com/KafClaw/GitClaw/actions/workflows/pull-db-tests.yml/badge.svg)](https://github.com/KafClaw/GitClaw/actions/workflows/pull-db-tests.yml) [![release-docker](https://github.com/KafClaw/GitClaw/actions/workflows/release-docker.yml/badge.svg)](https://github.com/KafClaw/GitClaw/actions/workflows/release-docker.yml) [![release](https://img.shields.io/github/v/release/KafClaw/GitClaw)](https://github.com/KafClaw/GitClaw/releases) [![license](https://img.shields.io/badge/license-MIT-blue.svg)](LICENSE) ## GitClaw Hard Fork This repository is a hard fork focused on building an agent-first, open source Git service for autonomous workflows. Why we hard-forked: - We need first-class machine-to-machine onboarding and collaboration. - We optimize for OpenClaw-compatible agent workflows, not only human web flows. - We move faster on product direction specific to agentic revision control. GitClaw remains MIT-licensed and based on Gitea, while evolving independently for this use case. ## Agent-First Features GitClaw adds an agent enrollment and policy model designed for production automation: - Public agent enrollment endpoint (`POST /api/v1/agents/enroll`) guarded by server policy. - Source network controls via CIDR allow lists in admin settings. - Agent identity normalization (`whoami@hostname` -> stable username format). - Bot/restricted account provisioning for enrolled agents. - Optional auto-creation of a bootstrap repository per enrolled agent. - Token issuance and token rotation on re-enrollment for existing agent accounts. - Skills-based onboarding with public `skill.md` and `scripts/enroll.sh`. - Login page and home hints for agent onboarding. Security direction: - No external request should use or require `security.INTERNAL_TOKEN`. - `INTERNAL_TOKEN` remains a server-internal primitive only. - Enrollment trust is policy-based (endpoint enablement, CIDR, admin controls). ## Purpose GitClaw is an agent-first Git service for self-hosted machine-to-machine workflows. It is built in Go and runs across Linux, macOS, and Windows on common architectures. ## Documentation GitClaw-specific docs: - [Agentic Enrollment Design](docs/agentic-enrollment.md) - [Agentic Operations Guide](docs/agentic-operations.md) - [Deployment Helpers](contrib/agent-enrollment/README.md) ## Building From the root of the source tree, run: TAGS="bindata" make build or if SQLite support is required: --- === demirag/gitclaw === # GitClaw ü¶û **GitHub for AI Agents** - A collaborative git hosting platform designed for AI agents to build together. ## üéØ Vision GitClaw is a git hosting platform where AI agents can: - Create and manage repositories - Collaborate on code with other agents - Share tools, skills, and libraries - Build complex projects together - Learn from each other's work Think of it as **GitHub + Moltbook** - combining git's power with agent social networking. ## üèóÔ∏è Architecture ### Tech Stack **Backend:** - ASP.NET Core 10 - LibGit2Sharp (git operations) - PostgreSQL (metadata) - Redis (caching) **Frontend:** - React 18 - TypeScript - Vite - Tailwind CSS **Infrastructure:** - Docker & Docker Compose - Azure (deployment) - Git repositories on filesystem ### Core Components 1. **Repository Service** - Create, manage, and access git repositories 2. **Git Protocol Server** - Handle git clone/push/pull operations (SSH & HTTPS) 3. **Web UI** - Browse repos, view commits, manage projects 4. **Agent Management** - Agent profiles, authentication, discovery 5. **Collaboration Tools** - Issues, tasks, code review ## üöÄ Quick Start ### Prerequisites - .NET 10 SDK - Node.js 18+ - PostgreSQL 14+ - Git ### Development Setup ```bash # Clone the repository git clone https://github.com/demirag/gitclaw.git cd gitclaw ---

done

content.text: {"created":"2026-02-19T11:53:58Z","description":"ü¶û UNDER DEVELOPMENT ü¶û A drop-in AI agent that runs entirely through GitHub ü¶û One folder, zero infrastructure: just open an issue and start chatting ü¶û Conversations are committed for persistent memory ü¶û Multi-provider LLM support","forks":0,"stars":1,"updated":"2026-02-22T03:09:06Z"}

Here's the full landscape:

---

## The GitClaw Ecosystem ‚Äî All Projects

### üèÜ Tier 1: The Origin

| Project | Stars | What it is |
|---------|-------|------------|
| **[SawyerHood/gitclaw](https://github.com/SawyerHood/gitclaw)** | ‚≠ê 205, 27 forks | **The original.** Personal AI assistant running on GitHub Actions via pi agent. Fork it, add an API key, chat via Issues. Clean, minimal, well-executed. |

### üî± Tier 2: Ambitious Forks & Namesakes

| Project | Stars | What it is |
|---------|-------|------------|
| **[ordinalOS/gitclaw](https://github.com/ordinalOS/gitclaw)** | ‚≠ê 4 | "AGI in GitHub" ‚Äî a heavily expanded fork with **25 agents across 5 plugins**: sarcastic coffee summaries, RPG bug quests, comedy PR reviews, GitHub Pages dashboards, weekly QA audits. The "maximalist" fork. |
| **[zavora-ai/gitclaw](https://github.com/zavora-ai/gitclaw)** | ‚≠ê 2 | **Completely different product** wearing the same name. A full **Git platform for AI agents** ‚Äî Rust/Actix-web backend, React frontend, cryptographic identity, signed commits, reputation system, SDKs in Python/TypeScript/Rust. Wants to be "GitHub but for agents." Has a website (gitclaw.dev), docs, Discord. |
| **[KafClaw/GitClaw](https://github.com/KafClaw/GitClaw)** | ‚≠ê 2 | **Hard fork of Gitea** ‚Äî a self-hosted Git server rebuilt for "machine-native" workflows. Agent enrollment endpoints, CIDR allow lists, bot account provisioning, token rotation. Written in Go. Production-oriented. |
| **[demirag/gitclaw](https://github.com/demirag/gitclaw)** | ‚≠ê 0 | "GitHub for AI Agents" ‚Äî ASP.NET Core + React platform for agents to collaborate on code. Similar vision to zavora-ai but different stack (C#, PostgreSQL, Redis). |
| **[japer-technology/gitclaw](https://github.com/japer-technology/gitclaw)** | ‚≠ê 1 | **This project.** Fork of SawyerHood's original, restructured as a drop-in `.GITCLAW/` addon with installer, extensive docs, help system, and chat tooling. |

### üå± Tier 3: Satellites & Spinoffs

| Project | Stars | What it is |
|---------|-------|------------|
| **[calamity10110/gitclawVul](https://github.com/calamity10110/gitclawVul)** | ‚≠ê 1 | Fork of SawyerHood's original, appears vulnerability-focused |
| **[AgentWorkforce/gitclawlab](https://github.com/AgentWorkforce/gitclawlab)** | ‚≠ê 1 | "Where AI agents host and deploy code" ‚Äî TypeScript |
| **[microchipgnu/gitclaw-template](https://github.com/microchipgnu/gitclaw-template)** | ‚≠ê 0 | Autonomous agent template ‚Äî wakes every 30 min, reads memory, acts |
| **[ledbetterljoshua/gitclawd](https://github.com/ledbetterljoshua/gitclawd)** | ‚≠ê 0 | "Git client with Claude built-in" ü¶û ‚Äî clever name pun |
| **[ntheenigma/GitClaw](https://github.com/ntheenigma/GitClaw)** | ‚≠ê 0 | "Moltbook but useful" ‚Äî HTML |
| **[efree19/Gitclaw](https://github.com/efree19/Gitclaw)** | ‚≠ê 0 | Empty, just created today |

### ü¶ï Tier 4: Unrelated

|---------|-------|------------|
| **[clawpack/gitclaw](https://github.com/clawpack/gitclaw)** | ‚≠ê 1 | **From 2014.** Tutorial for Clawpack (a scientific computing library). Nothing to do with AI. The OG "gitclaw" name holder. |

---

## Why japer-technology/gitclaw Should Rename

### 1. **The name is now a crowded, confused space**
In just ~3 weeks since SawyerHood created the original, "gitclaw" has fragmented into **at least 5 fundamentally different concepts** all sharing the same name:
- A GitHub Actions chatbot (SawyerHood ‚Äî the original)
- A full Git hosting platform for agents (zavora-ai)
- A Gitea hard fork for machine workflows (KafClaw)
- A multi-agent plugin system (ordinalOS)
- A drop-in repo addon (japer-technology ‚Äî you)

A user searching "gitclaw" has no way to distinguish these without clicking into each one.

### 2. **This project has diverged in identity, not just code**
japer-technology/gitclaw is no longer "SawyerHood's gitclaw with some tweaks." With 349 commits, an installer system, help docs, delivery methods, and a completely rewritten README, it has become a **different product with a different philosophy**. The original says "fork this repo." This project says "install this addon into any repo." That's a fundamentally different distribution model ‚Äî it deserves its own name.

### 3. **The "claw" metaphor doesn't match this project's character**
The original "gitclaw" name played off [OpenClaw](https://github.com/openclaw/openclaw) ‚Äî the lobster/claw branding. But this fork has evolved away from that lineage. It's not aggressive or extractive; it's a **quiet symbiont** that drops into a repo, sets up its own folder, and helps from the inside. "Claw" doesn't describe what it does.

### 4. **Fork confusion is a real problem**
GitHub shows "forked from SawyerHood/gitclaw" on the repo page. Users will assume it's a minor variant of the original. But it's not ‚Äî it's been fundamentally restructured. Keeping the name reinforces that false assumption. A rename would signal "this is its own thing."

### 5. **Namespace collisions will only get worse**
SawyerHood's original has 205 stars and 27 forks. As the ecosystem grows, more forks and derivatives will appear. If this project wants to establish its own identity ‚Äî especially with its installer-based distribution model that targets *other people's repos* ‚Äî it needs a name that won't be confused with the dozens of other gitclaw variants.

### 6. **The project already has its own branding**
It has a custom logo (`GITCLAW-LOGO.png`), a custom quickstart, its own documentation suite, and a `.GITCLAW/` folder convention. All of this could trivially be rebranded. The infrastructure for a rename is already in place.

---

**Bottom line:** "gitclaw" now means too many things to too many people. This project has earned its own name. Based on the earlier analysis, **GitLodger** (completely unclaimed) or **GitGraft** (effectively unclaimed) would clearly distinguish it while accurately describing what it actually does ‚Äî a self-contained agent that lodges/grafts into any GitHub repo.
